data.text: Food and Snacks for Bikepacking: Any Ideas?

What does everyone do for food while bikepacking? I am thinking of taking cup a soups, and some pasta sachets with various flavours, which you can simply add mix with water and simmer. Snackwise, i am looking at some protein/carb bars, and since its going to be a hot day, so high 5 dissolvable tablets for my water. Any one have thoughts on this ? do i need more? was thinking about maybe jerky or something that i can mix in with the pasta, to add more calories. Also was thinking about getting one of those insulated food bags, so I could store some more substancial for the morning, like some eggs, bacon, beans and sausages which i can then all throw into together for a hearty breakfast before I set off back home in the morning. Just not sure how practicale this would be with it being in a bag all day in the heat. Failing that, could just go with something simple like porridge
Freeze dried adventure food. It‚Äôs high calorie and doesn‚Äôt weigh much. Any quite tasty!
data.author: Laura Togwell

data.text: Yea, seen loads of that out and about, just not cheap, and for me, I would need a couple to keep me saited:)
data.author: Ray Breen

data.text: You need to pay close attention to the calories. After a day on the bike you will need a lot. Those pasta sachets need quite a bit of cooking and only give you around 300 cal, which isn't enough. Packet noodles cook faster and have around 500 calories.
data.author: Bridget McGill

data.text: Yea, that's what I picked up on when peps were discussing them. I think I am going to be a bit saddle sore, and maybe my legs too for the return trip, so the last thing I want is to be undernourished to add into the mix.
data.author: Ray Breen

data.text: Firepot dried food is excellent, just add boiling water and wait 10 minutes. I can highly recommend the Posh Baked Beans, 465 calories per pack. *Note* you will have a farty couple of hours after eating them.

data.author: Andy McMahon

data.text: Yea, thats my fallback, but seems a bit like cheating, but could be around the same price as some of dehydrated meal packs.
data.author: Ray Breen

data.text: Can‚Äôt beat porridge! The instant oats are the easy solution and the flavoured ones (blueberry!) taste ok made with water. The cheap option is to put some oats in a ziplock along with some raisins and a teaspoon of sugar! Mix with boiling water and leave for a few minutes and they‚Äôll be ready to eat at an edible temperature üëç Most of the pasta pre-packs are ok and some will ‚Äòcook‚Äô with same method - add to boiling water and leave to rehydrate for a few minutes. Mug shots I quite liked as an appetiser. Practice at home to find what you like. Salted peanuts, raisins, jelly beans, chocolate ‚Äòtrail mix‚Äô makes a good snack. Comments above on calories worth bearing in mind but depends how far you‚Äôre going!
data.author: Alex Crossland

data.text: Thanks bud, my first adventure is just short, an overnight with a total round trip of 60 miles give or take. My sedentary daily calorie intake is around 2500-3k, but taking into account the cycling, and all the setting up when i get to my destination, I estimate that I will need around 1-2k additional for each day. will have a better idea when i arrive, as i will be tracking the whole ride on my bike head unit.
data.author: Ray Breen

data.text: Too much ,mixed seeds ,eggs ,milk will cause severe constipation ..Ask me how I know ...I now use a lot of high 5 energy / electrolyte drink while on the bike & eat normally off .
data.author: Kevin Dean

data.text: Yea, i did a 100k fund raising ride last july, and thats all i took, high 5 syrups and some tablets for my water bottles
data.author: Ray Breen

data.text: Saves a lot of carry stuff ,I use to make all these cakes & bars with dates ,seeds etc as seen on GCN .. The high 5 stuff works for me , no cramps etc & easy to organise .
data.author: Kevin Dean

data.text: Now, folks, let me save you a fortune üôÇ Gels and powder drinks are a mix of sucralose and dextrose (different carbs) with flavourings. They're genuinely great, but the trouble is, gram for gram, crack cocaine is cheaper than that. What I do, I buy a big bag of dextrose online from a bodybuilding shop (it was something like 8 quid for five kilos), and then mix my own gloop or drink, whichever I want, with squash for flavour, and sometimes an espresso shot for extra fun. Works out something like 5p per gel's equivalent - and they're normally what, a quid each? Needless to say, the downside - apart from potential mess - is that you can't carry enough of this stuff for a long trip. So it's only for day rides; two days tops.
data.author: Pavel Bogolyubov

data.text: ah cool, thats a good idea, something for my list :)
data.author: Ray Breen

data.text: Everyone has their preferences. I am not fussy, and eat mostly instant noodles and couscous - quick to cook, which means less gas, and thus less weight. Tinned meat or fish added if I feel indulgent, but that's only a day or two after a shop - this stuff is a bugger to carry. Chocolate digestives are my Kryptonite - I can easily put away a pack in an evening, with a few mugs of tea (and yet I am still losing weight!). While riding - whatever carbs you can lay your hands on. Cereal bars, jelly sweets, malt loaves, even bread. Aldi/Lidl do all of the above that don't break the bank (you are likely to need them in some quantity), but further out, smaller shops have a lot less of a choice. If it's hot, you need electrolytes, or you'll be drinking non-stop; and you're the one carrying the water! Isotonic drinks are the best for physiological reasons, but they're heavy, expensive, and not always available. I buy large tubs of electrolyte pills from MyProtein, and they do the trick while not weighing anything to speak of, or taking any space.
data.author: Pavel Bogolyubov

data.text: Yea, i like the tablets, as they are very easy to transport, and as you say, weigh nothing.
data.author: Ray Breen

data.text: Recently got a dehydrator and vacuum pack machine. Dehydrated fruit, esp bananas and apricot were great. Also keeps home made jerkey fresh

data.text: yes, I think it‚Äôs more worth it if you‚Äôre going to vacuum pack stuff as it keeps it fresh etc. I‚Äôve always got a packet of banana on the bike now. Better than everything getting squished and sticky. Top ones are banana, apple, mango, kiwi, strawberries and apricot

data.text: That is pretty much it, instant oats, tortillas with peanut butter, pasta, rice, olives (you can buy them is packets), bars of different kinds, trail mix, don‚Äôt forget fruit or veg you can buy fresh, tomatoes, avo, cucumber, broccoli to steam or boil (I bring water to boil with broccoli inside, switch off gas let stand for 5, broccoli is then perfect)‚Ä¶

data.text: avocado, the perfect trail food.
data.author: Richard Brown

data.text: I dehydrate my own veg, add soya and quick noodles. Bisto do a chilli granules and bolognaise granules. Just add water and very light to carry. Get yourself a dehydrater, there well worth it.
data.author: Michelle Fuller

data.text: The humble tortilla/wrap is your friend. Easy to pack, lasts ages, fills you up, goes with anything. I like peanut butter & banana in mine or sausage & onions with a dash of curry powder if I'm cooking üíï

data.author: Ray Breen

data.text: My preference is sachets of porridge for breakfast(2) and coffee bags. Lunch is whatever I can find on the road with a preference for pies! Evening is either pub( best option) or noodles/ quick cook options etc. I always carry a fire pot type meal or two for emergencies. I would add that on a nice evening you don‚Äôt need to cook if you can find ready to eat food. Fuel is a significant weight!
data.author: Ian Ward

data.text: I use coffee sachets (whitener and coffee mix) and pain au chocolate (Aldi sell them in a packet of 8) for breakfasts. Then stop at a cafe for more. Just buy whatever you can at the other end in a shop if you are near civilisation.
data.author: Andrew Bucknall

data.text: pain au chocolate sounds a bit painful to me üôÇ yea, i want to to be self sufficient so when i go wild camping, i wont be as reliant on the local amenities
data.author: Ray Breen

data.text: You can get super high concentrated Robinson's squash to squirt into your bottle if you're bored of high5 or mix them up.
data.author: Andrew Bucknall

data.text: yes, thats right, i have this for my son when he is out and about, adding it to my list :D
data.author: Ray Breen

data.text: When I bikepacked from Land's End to home I couldn't eat enough. I was literally checking the calories of everything in the shop trying to get the calories in. After a few days of this I went to the pub and had two mains instead.

data.text: haha love it, yes sometimes you just cant beat a junky meal for carbs.
data.author: Ray Breen

data.text: Yup eating out of packets doesnt do it when you are burning lots of calories on a heavy bike. No substitute for real tasty food.
data.author: Jim McNeil

data.text: These are good. Asda. Otherwise, supernoodles or pot noodles. I usually start with a dehydrated meal from Decathlon (main, dessert and breakfast) then just get what I can as I go. Coffee bags or all in one sachets plus camomile tea for evenings. I‚Äôve added jerky to the noodles (chicken or beef) and it works well.
data.author: Adrian Uttley

data.text: I carry some ready to eat meals which you can but at places like Go Out Door etc these I call my emergency rations just in case I don't come across any shops. I'm told eggs don't travel wellüôÇ but seen a back packer guy take them out of the shells and out them in a plastice tube/bottle and they stayed together. For coffee I use the Nescaf√© range come with milk just add water and your sorted. Def bars but can be expensive so shop around I just get cereal bars from Tesco's or make my own flap jack'süëç

data.text:
Can't beat Fish and Chips for a good fill after a long day in the saddle! Failing that I try and keep a little stock of quick things like noodles/pasta/salads and have some cooked meats to put in. Less faf when at camp and I can concentrate on the ride üôÇ Just dropped my JOGLE Day 9 vid if you're interested..... https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=V1Y5RdBod_Y
Cycling John O'Groats to Lands End | Canals and locks! | Preston - Warrington | DAY 9 to Nantwich
youtube.com
data.author: Roadypacking

data.text: Just plan your route accordingly. In the UK with enough research you can find somewhere nice to eat every night if your budget allows. Ex forces so i have had my fill of eating ration pack style ready meals. They might give you enough calories but they taste like a dogs dinner a lot of the time and after a few days you really need something nice. You dont have to rough it in the UK unless you are in the far north of Scotland where the distances between food stops are longer.
data.author: Jim McNeil

data.text: Yea, if i end up doing longer trips, may mix roughing it meal wise with the odd pub meal
data.author: Ray Breen

data.text: nothing better after a long day of sitting down to a nice meal. Cant beat it. Camp food is fine for a day or two.
data.author: Jim McNeil

data.text: Summit to eat if going to remote places! Bachelors Pasta packets with tuna or mackerel or tesco meal deals
data.author: Nath Manning
